Award.AwardTitle: CREST Phase II: Cyber-ShARE Center of Excellence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cyber-ShARE ("Cyberinfrastructure for Sharing resources to Advance Research and Education") Center of Excellence at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) was established in 2007 with a mission to advance education and research through cyberinfrastructures that support information exchange and integration, as well as collaborative interdisciplinary research. The Center conducts research and prepares a workforce that can tackle some of the most challenging problems confronting society. The interdisciplinary research at the Center has resulted in tools and approaches that support scholarly interdisciplinary collaboration by facilitating the ability to share knowledge, concepts, approaches, and perspectives. As national leaders in the study of collaborative science and engineering, the Center has developed and applied models of team-based, cooperative learning, interdisciplinary teamwork, and knowledge integration. Areas of advancement in cyberinfrastructure (CI) have been in data management, data analysis, and virtual organizations in support of collaboration. In particular, CI research has focused on scientists' ability to document data collection and product development in ways that enable sharing and reuse of scientific results by enhancing results with provenance and other critical information.

The Center's crosscutting expertise is in collaboration and collaborative environments, semantic-based approaches to knowledge synthesis and representation (ontologies and provenance), and propagation of uncertainty in integrated analyses. The subprojects through which this expertise will transcend are as follows:

(1) Knowledge Representation, Negotiation and Integration: Linking Human and Machine Knowledge Models through Semantics

(2) Advancing Understanding of Ecosystem Processes Using Cyberinfrastructure

(3) Integrated Analysis for Development of 3-D Models of Earth Structure

Cyber-ShARE's research in analysis of climate change impacts on the environment and the modeling of Earth's structure has advanced through the Center's interdisciplinary approaches supported by CI. Our environmental science group is advancing understanding of carbon flux in extreme desert and arctic environments through innovative multi-scale data collection and analysis, along with novel methods for minimizing error propagation and ensuring data quality. Our geophysics research group is developing more accurate models of the Rio Grande Rift System through computational approaches to data integration and model fusion. The Center has developed novel tools that allow researchers to more effectively analyze the large amounts of data being collected through environmental and seismic sensor networks in these projects and around our nation. Sensor data are critical for understanding short and long term global change, enabling better understanding of the effects of climate change on water and energy, and the effects of earth structure on earthquake risk.

In the next phase of funding, the Cyber-ShARE Center will continue to conduct innovative, synergistic STEM research supported by CI in the areas of environmental science and geosciences. Among a large number of research questions to be investigated as part of the three subprojects are the following:

How can we create a machine understandable representation of individual mental models and integrated conceptual frameworks for interdisciplinary research, facilitated by advanced cyber-infrastructure?

What factors control land-atmosphere exchange of carbon, water and energy in desert and arctic terrestrial ecosystems and over what spatial and time scales?

How can Semantic Web technologies be used to enhance open access environmental data sharing, discovery, retrieval, integration, analysis, and visualization?

What is the evolution of the Rio Grande Rift and how does this relate to other active rifts, for example, the East Africa Rift System?

Can scientists understand, believe and accept new insights in the tectonic evolution of the southwest (and other regions) that were produced through the development of CI and CI-based applications that can seamlessly integrate and optimally fuse existing information sources?

The Center is critical to broadening training and education of interdisciplinary, CI-knowledgeable citizens, including STEM students who receive advanced degrees and represent the 21st century demographics. Compared to the national averages for graduate students in geology and environmental and computer science (NSF 2008), Cyber-ShARE students are 82.7% Hispanic while the national average is 4.7%, and 36.5% female while the national average is 30.8%. The Center aims to reach even higher levels of involvement of citizens from underrepresented groups during Phase II. The Center will extend the network of Cyber-ShARE collaborations to include other major CI projects, international collaborators, and industry partners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF CREST Cyber-ShARE Center of Excellence at The University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) was established with a mission to advance and integrate cyber-enhanced, collaborative, and interdisciplinary education and research through technologies that support the acquisition, exchange, analysis, and integration of data, information, and knowledge to solve complex problems. The Center's goals are to conduct innovative, synergistic STEM research supported by CI;  broaden training and education of interdisciplinary, CI-knowledgeable citizens; and extend the network of Cyber-ShARE collaborations.

Cyber-ShARE's commitment to interdisciplinary research incorporated three synergistic activities: engaging in the practice of interdisciplinary research; developing tools to support interdisciplinary research; and investigating the process of interdisciplinary research.  

The iLink subproject focused on knowledge representation, negotiation, and integration; the research defined methodologies for collaborative ontology development and knowledge graphs for describing scientific resources from different perspectives.  The various methodologies enabled the representation of resources, metrics, and provenance models that foster understanding and reuse of scientific resources in different contexts by a wide variety of stakeholders including non-experts. Results of this research have been applied to the areas of Smart Cities and Water Sustainability.

The iFuse subproject focused on integrated analysis for the development of 3-D models of Earth's structure.  The iFuse subproject developed new approaches for data analysis that allowed earth scientists to answer fundamental scientific questions about the Earth and its structure. The research resulted in high-quality 3-D Earth models by using a highly integrated, multidisciplinary approach that fuses different types of information from a variety of sources and with varying accuracy, sensitivity, and resolution and considers available geological and geophysical constraints and uncertainty levels. In particular, the researchers developed 3-D Earth models in various tectonic provinces in the southwest US (New Mexico, Texas, and Oklahoma) using seismic data collected from the NSF EarthScope program and are finalizing 3-D Earth models in other tectonic environments in Colombia, Libia, and Costa Rica.  

The iSense subproject focused on advancing the utility of cyberinfrastructure in Environmental Science.  The subproject developed software, hardware, and data products that have been used locally and internationally to identify factors affecting ecosystem structure and function in arctic and desert ecosystems over multiple spatio-temporal scales. The data from the project contributes to national and international networks. iSense examined how uncertainty propagates from systematic error in cumulative flux estimates derived from data collected using eddy covariance towers measuring land-atmosphere carbon, water, and energy exchange, and developed approaches for enhancing environmental data integration, discovery, access, and visualization in Web mapping applications. A patent was awarded for a smart camera system with a trigger system that responds to multiple sensors, time steps, and other programmable dependencies. Another outcome is a novel image analysis software analyzes spectral properties and temporal change in multiple areas of interest and color spaces in time-lapse image time series.

Cyber-ShARE researchers and staff leveraged findings from the new field of "science of team science," cognitive and learning sciences, social sciences, and communication theory to generate and test team activities that facilitate combining knowledge across disciplines. This has led to the development of best practices for leading these kinds of complex, interdisciplinary research activities.

Cyber-ShARE researchers established numerous collaborations with local, regional, national, and international partners. This includes national laboratories, industry, universities, K-12 education, and entities from the public- and private-sectors.

Cyber-ShARE created the Expertise Connector online tool (http://expertise.utep.edu) to support the discovery of expertise and communities of practice (CoP) at UTEP.  The CoP support researchers and educators who share common interests and desire to collaborate. In collaboration with Virginia Tech, Cyber-ShARE developed the ENGAGE Tool, to manage student-success information.  

Cyber-ShARE contributed to the growth of the interdisciplinary Computational Science program and reinvigoration of the Environmental Science and Engineering program since 2015. The Department of Computer Science received approval in 2020 to begin a Master's of Science in Data and Informational Sciences, an interdisciplinary program.  Cyber-ShARE funded 48 undergraduate students, 48% were female and 88% were from underrepresented ethnic groups; 25 students graduated with a Master's degree, 40% were female, and 68% were from underrepresented ethnic groups; 18 students completed a Ph.D., 22% were female, and 78% were from underrepresented ethnic groups. 

The influence of Cyber-ShARE's interdisciplinary efforts at UTEP is evidenced by UTEP hiring an interdisciplinary network manager and technical staff, and its investment in a new Interdisciplinary Research Building (IDRB), the first building to be solely dedicated to interdisciplinary research on the UTEP campus. The IDRB will house the Visualization & Interactive Collaboration (VizInC) Laboratory, which will be managed by Cyber-ShARE's enterprise systems programmer and will support interdisciplinary research and education. The CREST Cyber-ShARE Center of Excellence will continue to support interdisciplinary research at UTEP with direct report to the VP of Research and Sponsored Projects.
